body_str: : The applicant argues that he should have been given an oral hearing before a final decision was made on his application pursuant to s. 114(2) of the
. That application seeks permission to apply for permanent residence from within Canada on the ground that humanitarian and compassionate grounds exist for such permission to be given.
I think it is clear from the jurisprudence that the requirements of natural justice do not make the holding of an oral hearing mandatory in this case. See, for example,
<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  F.C. 728, at p. 735  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  Imm. L.R.(2d) 152, at p. 156 F.T.R.

As counsel for the respondent argues, while personal interviews may be required when a marriage is the basis for the humanitarian and compassionate review claim, such is not the case when that claim can be decided on the basis that all evidence which is put forward by the claimant is accurate. In the former the bona fides of the marriage must be assessed and this requires an evaluation by the immigration officer of the applicant's evidence and an explanation of any inconsistencies which may exist in it or between it and other evidence. In the latter, all that is required by the officer is a weighing of the sufficiency of the evidence which is assumed to be accurate. There was no explanation of inconsistencies or evaluation of the truthfulness of the evidence required in the present case; thus an oral hearing is not required.
